FacilityStr1: 11.9 miles SSW of New Town, ND

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan
Arikara Pad
WPX Energy Williston, LLC

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Torrent Energy Services (Torrent) operates two MRUs designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Arikara 15-22H Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.

The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, with an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The MRU system can generate temperatures as low as -20°F.  Torrent uses this system to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the units allow them to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The NGL storage tanks have an 18,000 gallon capacity. Torrent will have four tanks onsite and the maximum fill for each tank is 14,400 gallons. The 57,600 gallons is equivalent to 328,896 lbs. of flammable liquids.

Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs. Torrent can store approximately 328,896 lbs. of NGL which exceeds the 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule and must prepare a RMP.

LOCATION

The Arikara 15-22H Pad is located in the SE ¼ of the SW ¼ and the SW ¼ of the SE ¼ of section 10 and the NE ¼ of the NW ¼ and the NW ¼ of the NE ¼ of section 15, Township 150N, Range 93W, Mountrail County, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (FBIR).

Latitude: 47.818002, Longitude: -102.567878

DRIVING DIRECTIONS

Proceed in a Southerly direction from New Town, ND along 89th Ave NW/West Ave. approximately 3.1 mi to the junction of this road and 36th St. NW; turn Right and proceed in a Westerly direction approximately 3.0 mi to the junction of this road and 92nd Ave. NW; turn Left and proceed in a Southerly direction approximately 7.1 mi to a point where the road begins to curve East; turn right and proceed on an existing road in a Westerly direction for 0.1 miles to the point where the existing access road bears to the left; turn Left and proceed in a Southerly direction for 1.2 mi to the existing well location.
 
DISPERSION MODELING ANAYSIS WITH RMP*COMP

RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis
Scenario Summary
March 13, 2018

Chemical Name 	                CAS Number	Quantity Released (pounds)
Butane 	                        106-97-8	75863
Ethane 	                         74-84-0	22082
Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl]   75-28-5  	23309
Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-] 	78-78-4	        19592
Methane 	                74-82-8 	 451
Pentane     	                109-66-0	40477
Propane 	                 74-98-6	147122

Threat type: 	Flammable 
Scenario type: 	Worst-case 
Release type: 	Vapor Cloud Explosion 
 Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.6 miles (0.9 kilometers)  

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT

After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the

distance to the flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.

A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.6 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
